intro: Oxytropis kamtschatica, commonly known as Kamtschatka locoweed, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of eastern Russia and parts of northern Asia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its legume fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments. It produces small, pea-like flowers that range in color from white to purple, and its leaves are usually compound with small, oval-shaped leaflets. Oxytropis kamtschatica is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to grazing animals.
